documentation_assessment: CRITICAL DEFICIENCIES IDENTIFIED: This change exhibits fundamentally inadequate documentation for a user-facing workspace configuration change. Implementation plan states 'N/A' - completely unacceptable for hiding UI fields in CSM/FSM Agent Workspace that affects end-user workflows. Rollback plan is empty, creating unmitigated risk if field hiding breaks dependent functionality. Test plan states 'N/A' despite modifying user interface elements that require validation across multiple workspace views. Justification reads 'Requested by Igor' with zero business context, stakeholder approval documentation, or impact analysis. The description mentions hiding Comments/Work Notes fields and relying on Activity Stream, but provides no technical implementation method (Form Designer, UI Policy, Client Script, ACL), no affected workspace inventory, no dependency analysis, and no user communication strategy. Update Set field references three batch update sets but no validation documentation accompanies them. This level of documentation would fail basic change management governance in any mature organization.
risks: CRITICAL - Clone freshness: Clone info unavailable for mobizuat; cannot validate changes against sub-production environment before production deployment, violating fundamental pre-prod validation principles
CRITICAL - Environment undefined: CMDB record shows environment field is empty, making it impossible to determine target environment characteristics or associated maintenance windows
HIGH - Missing rollback plan: Zero documented procedure to restore Comments/Work Notes field visibility if Activity Stream fails, users revolt, or hidden fields break integrations/automations
HIGH - Undefined implementation method: No specification of HOW fields will be hidden (Form Designer, UI Policy, ACL, Client Script) creates execution ambiguity and deployment risk
HIGH - Workspace scope uncertainty: 'CSM/FSM Workspace' is vague - could affect Agent Workspace, Mobile, Service Portal, or multiple workspace variants without explicit inventory

HIGH - Dependency blindness: Hiding Comments/Work Notes fields may break client scripts, business rules, workflows, integrations, or reports that reference these fields - no dependency analysis documented

MEDIUM - Activity Stream single point of failure: Change assumes Activity Stream/Compose pane will replace commenting functionality but provides no validation that Activity Stream is operational, properly configured, or accepted by users
MEDIUM - Zero user validation: No evidence of CSM/FSM business owner approval, end-user acceptance testing, or pilot program - users may reject workflow change
MEDIUM - Training gap: No documented user communication or change management plan for agents transitioning from traditional comment fields to Activity Stream
MEDIUM - Mobile/Service Portal impact: No mention of how field hiding affects mobile apps or Service Portal views where Activity Stream may not be available
MEDIUM - Update Set validation gap: Three update sets referenced (Parent + 2 Children) but no collision detection, dependency documentation, or sequence validation provided

LOW - Template misalignment: Template 'ServiceNow Platform Updates' with 100% success rate across 505 changes suggests routine platform maintenance, but this change is custom workspace UI configuration - template may be incorrectly applied

MANDATORY - Create rollback plan: Document specific steps to restore Comments/Work Notes field visibility including configuration rollback procedure, update set reversion steps, cache clearing requirements, and validation checkpoints

MANDATORY - Develop comprehensive test plan: Include (1) field visibility verification across all workspace variants, (2) Activity Stream functionality validation, (3) comment creation/editing/viewing workflows, (4) mobile app testing, (5) Service Portal impact assessment, (6) integration testing for systems reading/writing comments, (7) business rule/client script dependency validation, (8) user acceptance testing with representative CSM/FSM agents
